As we look towards economic recovery after the pandemic, we need to focus on how we’re building an economy that works for working women.

This past year was particularly hard. Women bore the brunt of the economic fallout of pandemic, overwhelmingly shouldered the burden of child care as schools shut down, and risked their lives as frontline workers.
Women in #NJ11 who work full time make on average around $20K less than men. That wage gap only widens for women of color.
On #EqualPayDay, we must recognize the wage gap isn’t just a women's issue, it’s an economic issue, a family issue, and an equity issue.

The greatest threat to our security right now is the threat of domestic terrorism, and the tensions and polarization between us. Taking on this threat is my top priority as Chair of this Subcommittee. http://pbs.twimg.com/amplify_video_thumb/1374737949116526597/img/EfjLeeSE2L_RbXmb.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1374737949116526597/vid/480x270/CZ2o0X8Gz3mIE9m4.mp4?tag=14

LIVE NOW: Our first public hearing of the Subcommittee on Intel & Counterterrorism. State & local officials are on the front lines of the fight against domestic terrorism - today we’re hearing from them about steps we can take to ensure Americans’ safety. https://homeland.house.gov/activities/hearings/state-and-local-responses-to-domestic-terrorism-the-attack-on-the-us-capitol-and-beyond

I wanted to break down how we plan to tackle these really consequential issues and our agenda for the work ahead of us. As Chair, it’s my hope we can demonstrate how leaders from both sides of the aisle can work on these issues without it being a vitriolic fight.

January 6 was the kickoff of a new era in national security, where the greatest threats to the US are the internal division between us, and addressing the surge in domestic terrorism and violent extremism is our mission on the Subcommittee on Intel & Counterterrorism. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/ExMxYFcUcAEK6SX.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1374492466397671435/vid/480x270/bm3SAdavIgfFjDwW.mp4?tag=14

Thank you to our tele-town panelists from FEMA, NEMA, and the American Red Cross. I also thank everyone who called in. #NE02 has a great group of dedicated professionals—from law enforcement to emergency management groups to healthcare providers, they are here and ready to serve!
Rep. Bacon: The main takeaway for tonight is to make a plan and be prepared […] You just never know during this time of the year. That was the main goal for this tele-town hall. #BaconTeleTownHall

Rep. Bacon: I serve on the Defense Critical Supply Chain Task Force to ensure America’s supply chain is independent, reliable, and accessible so that other countries like China will not dominate our supply chain. #BaconTeleTownHall

Q: On landlords kicking renters out?
Rep. Bacon: Congress passed five COVID bills that provided rental relief […] Beyond that, we also tried to help people stay employed by the #PPP so people can keep their paychecks and keep up with rent. #BaconTeleTownHall

Q: Protecting minorities during emergencies?
Bacon: FEMA is always willing to help those impacted financially.
FEMA: We're ensuring equitable vaccine distribution & are reaching out to our most vulnerable populations & demographics.
Red Cross: We serve everyone the same.

Rep. Don Bacon: We know the Russians and Chinese would like to take down our energy grid. We’re working hard at the national level to deter that […] Our country has to be prepared to counter that and protect our energy sector. #BaconTeletownHall

Jay Van Der Werff, Ph. D. (FEMA):We have a tribal liaison who works with all federally recognized tribes and their leaders […] We’ve been working with them through COVID and have worked with the Tribal Emergency Managers to be prepared for any emergencies.

Rep. Don Bacon: Thank you to the teamwork of volunteers, law enforcement, the Governor, FEMA, and others for responding to the 2019 floods. I also thank those who worked in the shelters and provided assistance to so many of our residents. #BaconTeleTownHall

Rep. Don Bacon: Even before COVID, I introduced bills in Congress that have prepared us for pandemics [...] bills that would increase mask production and improve medical surge capacity at facilities like UNMC. #BaconTeleTownHall

Q: Is Nebraska ready for the next disaster?
Earl Imler (NEMA): Everything we’re being told right now is we’re having more than adequate room for snowpack. […] We’re actually in a good position. Experts do not have any concern for floods overall, but there is always a chance.

Jay Van Der Werff, Ph. D. (FEMA): "Ready Campus" helps gather students and other volunteers. Check with your local community-based organizations that are looking for volunteers to help in an emergency. We would love to have students participate. #BaconTeletownHall

Weysan Dun (Red Cross): If your family resides in different states, make a plan—We recommend you pick two separate locations to meet. Have an alternate way of transportation besides car. Plan other ways to communicate other than your cell phone. #BaconTeletownHall

Weysan Dun (Red Cross): We work with NEMA & County Emergency Management. We are ready to set up shelters, anywhere from a handful of people to a couple hundred people. All of these shelters are intended to be temporary. Our goal is to help with immediate needs. #BaconTeletownHall

Weysan Dun (Red Cross): The Red cross also offers many free, online emergency education programs (in many different languages). They’re also available for all ages. […] We also have a program called "Be Red Cross Ready." #BaconTeletownHall

Weysan Dun (American Red Cross): The Red Cross has conducted surveys & only 45% of American households have an emergency preparedness plan. We encourage everyone to create a plan and make a kit, even if you get separated from your family during an emergency. #BaconTeletownHall

Earl Imler (NEMA): 3 important websites to know:
➡️http://Nema.nebraska.gov
➡️http://Neprep.org
➡️http://Ready.gov
I highly recommend creating a work and personal safety kit for you and your family.

Jay Van Der Werff, Ph. D. (FEMA): Having a national weather service radio or receiving severe notifications from phone apps is always helpful […] FEMA also offers preparedness kits online. #BaconTeleTownHall

Jay Van Der Werff, Ph.D. (FEMA): We’re entering our severe weather season […] One thing you can do is participate in the National Flood Insurance Program. […] Floods can happen anytime anywhere. It’s always best to be prepared now, rather than later. #BaconTeleTownHall
REMINDER: Our emergency preparedness tele-town hall goes LIVE in 30 minutes! Residents of #NE02 can call 855-920-0558 to ask a question, or they can listen in at https://bacon.house.gov/live/.

So long as the filibuster remains in place, efforts to reform our gun laws, strengthen voting rights and address climate change will be held hostage by this undemocratic rule of Senate procedure. Give Americans the legislative voice they deserve. Abolish the filibuster.

Throughout history, the filibuster was used to block landmark civil rights legislation, uphold segregation and deny protections for African Americans. It’s a relic of Jim Crow that has no place in our lawmaking process today.

Republicans will say that the filibuster was created intentionally to make the Senate more bipartisan. But, that’s simply not true. Not only does the Constitution make no mention of this procedural wall, but it assumes that legislative decisions would be made by *majority* vote.

The filibuster allows lawmakers elected by a minority of voters to exercise veto power over any and all laws-even on issues that the majority of the American people support. For instance, while nearly 70% of Americans support gun reform, we still may never see reform of any kind.
To protect Americans from gun violence, we need to fundamentally change how the government works: We need to abolish the filibuster. Let me tell you why.  🧵

We must also cut back on spending to lower our debt. My Finding Federal Savings Committee Resolution will identify and either eliminate or modify underperforming and nonessential federal programs to save money and streamline the bloated federal bureaucracy.

My Balanced Budget Constitutional Amendment will prevent further growth of the national debt by requiring the federal government to do what every American family across the country must do - make sure their spending does not exceed the amount of money they bring in every year.

The U.S. currently has a debt of over $28 trillion; that’s $84,850 for every American citizen. If we allow that debt to continue to rise, we'll see fewer jobs, higher prices at the grocery store, less improvements on our roads, decreased home values and higher mortgage payments.

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems advanced H.R. 1951, “Increase Federal Disaster Cost Share Act of 2021,” to increase to no less than 90% the federal share for all major disaster declarations granted in 2020.
MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 1921, to amend the “Federal Water Pollution Act,” to reauthorize the Lake Pontchartrain Basin Restoration Program.

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 587, “Ocean Pollution Reduction Act II,” to provide the Point Loma Wastewater Treatment Plant in San Diego, California with a path forward for reducing pollution and implementing an innovative water recycling program.

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 1144, “Promoting United Government Efforts to Save our Sound Act,” to support restoration efforts in WA’s Puget Sound, and authorize $50M in federal funds annually for five years for restoration activities.

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 2016, Federal Disaster Assistance Coordination Act,” to help federal agencies streamline and consolidate information collection and Preliminary Damage Assessments following disasters.
MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 539, “Preventing Disaster Revictimization Act,” to improve the delivery of disaster relief assistance to individuals and households.

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 1917, “Hazard Eligibility and Local Projects Act,” to expedite the start of certain types of projects following Presidentially-declared disasters while awaiting FEMA's full approval.

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 1703, “National Children’s Museum Act,” to direct the Administrator of the General Services Administration to enter into a cooperative agreement w/ the National Children’s Museum to provide the museum space at no cost.
MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 390, to redesignate a federal building in Memphis, Tennessee, as the “Odell Horton Federal Building.”

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 1262, “Notice to Airmen Improvement Act of 2021,” requiring the FAA to establish a task force to review the current process to notify pilots and others about potential hazards in the airspace or at an airport.

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 468, “Expedited Delivery of Airport Infrastructure Act of 2021,” to allow U.S. airports to utilize Airport Improvement Program funds to incentive faster completion of airport infrastructure projects.

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 1765, “Washington Channel Public Access Act,” to prohibit the Secretary of the Army and the @USACEHQ from finalizing, implementing, or enforcing a proposed rule that restricts public access to the 
Washington Channel.

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems and @TransportGOP advanced H.R. 2008, Local Water Protection Act,” bipartisan legislation to reauthorize EPA grants that help states manage nonpoint water pollution from sources such as farms and cities.

MARKUP ALERT: @TransportDems advanced an Amendment in the Nature of a Substitute to H.R. 610, San Francisco Bay Restoration Act, to establish a new regional program within EPA to help restore the San Francisco Bay under the Clean Water Act.
